Detailed Description

Base class for implementing application Instrumentation.

Base class for implementing application Instrumentation code. When running with Instrumentation turned on, this class will be instantiated for you before any of the application code, allowing you to monitor all of the interaction the system has with the application. An Instrumentation implementation is described to the system through an AndroidManifest.xml's <instrumentation> tag.

 // Header file: InstrumentationTest.h
 #include <gaia/core/Instrumentation.h>
 #include <gaia/core/Persistence.h>
 class InstrumentationTest : public gaia::core::Instrumentation
 {
 public:
     InstrumentationTest();
     virtual ~InstrumentationTest();
     virtual void onCreate(gaia::core::Persistence* arguments);
     virtual void onStart();
 };
 
 // Implementation file
 #include "InstrumentationTest.h"
 using namespace gaia::core;
 
 InstrumentationTest::InstrumentationTest() {
     // Do something.
 }
 
 InstrumentationTest::~InstrumentationTest() {
 }
 
 void InstrumentationTest::onCreate(Persistence* arguments) {
     // Do something before loading application code.
 }
 
 void InstrumentationTest::onStart() {
     // Do something to interacte with target application in a separate thread.
     // The target application is set in the android:targetPackage attribute
     // in AndroidManifest.xml
 }

void gaia::core::Instrumentation::finish ( int32_t  resultCode,
Persistence *  results 
)

Terminate instrumentation of the application.

This will cause the application process to exit, removing this instrumentation from the next time the application is started.

Parameters:
resultCodeOverall success/failure of instrumentation.
resultsAny results to send back to the code that started the instrumentation.
Context* gaia::core::Instrumentation::getContext ( )

Return the Context of this Instrumentation's package.

Note that this is often different than the Context of the application being Instrumentationed, since the Instrumentation code often lives is a different package than that of the application it is running against. See getTargetContext to retrieve a Context for the target application.

Returns:
The Instrumentation's package context.
See also:
getTargetContext
Context* gaia::core::Instrumentation::getTargetContext ( )

Return a Context for the target application being Instrumentationed.

Note that this is often different than the Context of the Instrumentation code, since the Instrumentation code often lives is a different package than that of the application it is running against. See getContext to retrieve a Context for the Instrumentation code.

Returns:
A Context in the target application.
See also:
getContext

gaia::testing::MockPage *  parent,
Context *  context,
Demand *  demand 
)

Perform instantiation of an Page object.

This method is intended for use with unit tests, such as gaia/testing/PageUnitTestCase. The page will be useable locally but will be missing some of the linkages necessary for use within the sytem.

Parameters:
classNameThe ClassName of the desired Page
parentThe parent Page (if any)
contextThe base context for the activity to use
demandThe demand that started this Page
Returns:
Returns the instantiated page
virtual void gaia::core::Instrumentation::onCreate ( Persistence *  arguments) [virtual]

Called when the Instrumentation is starting, before any application code has been loaded.

Usually this will be implemented to simply start the Instrumentation thread, which will then continue execution in onStart.

If you do not need your own thread -- that is you are writing your Instrumentation to be completely asynchronous (returning to the event loop so that the application can run), you can simply begin your Instrumentation here, for example call Context#startPage to begin the appropriate first page of the application.

Parameters:
argumentsAny additional arguments that were supplied when the instrumentation was started.

Reimplemented in gaia::testing::InstrumentationTestRunner.

virtual void gaia::core::Instrumentation::onDestroy ( ) [virtual]

Called when the instrumented application is stopping, after all of the normal application cleanup has occurred.

virtual void gaia::core::Instrumentation::onStart ( ) [virtual]

Method where the instrumentation thread enters execution.

This allows you to run your instrumentation code in a separate thread than the application, so that it can perform blocking operation such as sendKeySync or startPageSync.

You will typically want to call finish() when this function is done, to end your instrumentation.

Reimplemented in gaia::testing::InstrumentationTestRunner.

void gaia::core::Instrumentation::runOnMainSync ( gaia::core::WorkItem *  workItem)

Execute a call on the application's main thread, blocking until it is complete.

Useful for doing things that are not thread-safe, such as looking at or modifying the view hierarchy.

Parameters:
workItemThe code to run on the main thread.
void gaia::core::Instrumentation::sendCharacterSync ( int32_t  keyCode)

Higher-level method for sending both the down and up key events for a particular character key code.

Equivalent to creating both KeyEvent objects by hand and calling sendKeySync. The event appears as if it came from keyboard 0, the built in one.

Parameters:
keyCodeThe key code of the character to send.
void gaia::core::Instrumentation::sendKeyDownUpSync ( int32_t  key)

Sends an up and down key event sync to the currently focused window.

Parameters:
keyThe integer keycode for the event.

Referenced by gaia::testing::InstrumentationTestCase< TestFixture >::sendKeys(), and gaia::testing::InstrumentationTestCase< TestFixture >::sendRepeatedKeys().

void gaia::core::Instrumentation::sendKeySync ( KeyEvent *  event)

Send a key event to the currently focused window/view and wait for it to be processed.

Finished at some point after the recipient has returned from its event processing, though it may not have completely finished reacting from the event -- for example, if it needs to update its display as a result, it may still be in the process of doing that.

Parameters:
eventThe event to send to the current focus.
void gaia::core::Instrumentation::sendPointerSync ( MotionEvent *  event)

Dispatch a pointer event.

Finished at some point after the recipient has returned from its event processing, though it may not have completely finished reacting from the event -- for example, if it needs to update its display as a result, it may still be in the process of doing that.

Parameters:
eventA motion event describing the pointer action.

void gaia::core::Instrumentation::sendTrackballEventSync ( MotionEvent *  event)

Dispatch a trackball event.

Finished at some point after the recipient has returned from its event processing, though it may not have completely finished reacting from the event -- for example, if it needs to update its display as a result, it may still be in the process of doing that.

Parameters:
eventA motion event describing the trackball action.
void gaia::core::Instrumentation::setAutomaticPerformanceSnapshots ( )
void gaia::core::Instrumentation::setInTouchMode ( bool  inTouch)

Force the global system in or out of touch mode.

This can be used if your Instrumentation relies on the UI being in one more or the other when it starts.

Parameters:
inTouchSet to true to be in touch mode, false to be in focus mode.
void gaia::core::Instrumentation::start ( )

Create and start a new thread in which to run instrumentation.

This new thread will call to onStart where you can implement the instrumentation.

Page* gaia::core::Instrumentation::startPageSync ( Demand *  demand)

Start a new page and wait for it to begin running before returning.

In addition to being synchronous, this method as some semantic differences from the standard Context#startPage call: the page component is resolved before talking with the page manager (its class name is specified in the Demand that this method ultimately starts), and it does not allow you to start pages that run in a different process. In addition, if the given Demand resolves to multiple pages, instead of displaying a dialog for the user to select an page, an exception will be thrown.

The function returns as soon as the page goes idle following the call to its Page#onInit. Generally this means it has gone through the full initialization including Page#onResume and drawn and displayed its initial window.

Parameters:
demandDescription of the page to start.
See also:
Context::startPage

Referenced by gaia::testing::InstrumentationTestCase< TestFixture >::launchPageWithDemand().

void gaia::core::Instrumentation::startPerformanceSnapshot ( )
void gaia::core::Instrumentation::startProfiling ( )

This method will start profiling if isProfiling() returns true.

You should only call this method if you set the handleProfiling attribute in the manifest file for this Instrumentation to true.

void gaia::core::Instrumentation::stopProfiling ( )

Stops profiling if isProfiling() returns true.

void gaia::core::Instrumentation::waitForIdleSync ( )

Synchronously wait for the application to be idle.

Can not be called from the main application thread -- use start to execute Instrumentation in its own thread.

Referenced by gaia::testing::InstrumentationTestCase< TestFixture >::launchPageWithDemand(), gaia::testing::InstrumentationTestCase< TestFixture >::sendKeys(), and gaia::testing::InstrumentationTestCase< TestFixture >::sendRepeatedKeys().
